instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Repaired this board liquid damaged. sold on ebay to a repair shop,  buyer claimed the board would not power on for 3 min or something like that.  got it back and the shop was using the customers computer for its testing they included a fan that was broken so hence why he thought it would not boot. and he killed the the video output by obviously using the customers screen.  so now i'm trying to fix this. i get no power on legs 1 2 5 6 on the <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>. 8.56v on pin 4 and 8.3v on pin 3.  check ohms on <RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR>, Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>, and <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>, with no changes. any ideas?  
Thanks 
Nate

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Update i just noticed that i did not put the right reading... pin 5 is 0v and pin 2 is 0v.  <CHIP>U2071</CHIP> i have 3v on pin 5 but 0v on pin 1, would you suspect the <CHIP>U2071</CHIP> to be dead(i need to look and see how 3vs0 gets to pin 1 if it comes from pin 5 or from the other side of the board)? also pin 2 and 3 are also 0v on the <CHIP>U2071</CHIP>.  <RESISTOR>R1430</RESISTOR> is 0v and that goes to the cpu.  could he have fried the cpu?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I doubt you have 0V on pin 1 of <CHIP>U2071</CHIP> as that would kill <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL>.....

Did you even check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Okay your def right about that! i have 3.32v on pin 1 not sure how i miss read that.  I did check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> it is 3.32v.
 i do not have anything on pin 4 and 2 still though

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Do you have an LCD connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes LCD connected for all test results.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I will ask again for voltage on pin 2 and 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> and if there is an image on the LCD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Okay 0v on pin 2 and pin 5 of the <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>.  Defiantly no image on the LCD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Pffff, the LCD is not recognized. Check all caps and resistors in the DP lines <CAPACITOR>C8320</CAPACITOR> and friends. Inspect connector for damage. 
Of course there will never be backlight if you don't even have an image.
